Exponentiated Quadratic Covariance

Source: R/gp_functions.R
cov_exp_quad.Rd

Generate a \(N \times N\) covariance matrix, \(\Sigma\), by passing a distance vector x to the exponentiated quadratic kernel function:

$$\Sigma_{ij} = \alpha^2 \exp \left( \frac{|x_i - x_j|^2}{-2 \ \rho} \right) + \delta_{ij} \ \sigma$$

where \(\alpha^2\) is the amplitude, \(\rho\) is the length_scale, and \(\sigma\) is a small offset along the diagonal to allow for additional variation.

Usage

cov_exp_quad(x, amplitude = 1, length_scale = 1, delta = 1e-09)

Arguments

x

A vector containing positions

amplitude

Numeric, controls the vertical scale of the covariance function

length_scale

Numeric, controls the horizontal scale of the covariance function

delta

A small offset added along the diagonal to ensure that the function returns a positive-semidefinite matrix. Larger values allow for increased variation at individual positions along the vector x.

Value

A \(N \times N\) symmetric, positive-semidefinite covariance matrix

Examples

x <- 1:12
cov_exp_quad(x)
#>               [,1]         [,2]         [,3]         [,4]         [,5]
